explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified into Category 2 since flash point 7 degC (closed-cup) (IMDG (2006)) is <23 degC and initial boiling point 111 - 112 degC (Ullmanns (E) (2003)) is >35 degC. The substance is classified into Class 3, Subsidiary risk 6.1 and 8, PG II in UNRTDG (UN2359).

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Classified into Type G since the substance is classified into Class 3, Subsidiary risk 6.1and 8, PG II in UNRTDG (UN2359) though there are chemical groups (unsaturated bond) present in the molecule associated with self-reactive properties.

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified into Not classified since the substance is classified into Class 3, Subsidiary risk 6.1 and 8, PG III in UNRTDG (UN2359) and not classified into upper Class 4.2 though no data are available.

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: The chemical structure of the substance does not contain metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At).

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Organic compounds containing no oxygen, fluorine or chlorine

organic_peroxides.rationale: Organic compounds containing no bivalent -O-O- structure

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on a LD50 value of 0.578 g/kg for rats (PATTY (5th, 2001)), the substance was classified into Category 4.

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on a LD50 value of 0.356 mL/kg (281.24 mg/kg) for rabbits (PATTY (5th, 2001)), the substance was classified into Category 3.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: Based on a LC50 value of 2755 ppm/4h for rats (PATTY (5th, 2001)), the substance was classified into Category 4. Since the test was conducted at lower than 90% of saturated vapour pressure concentration (26578 ppm), the classification criteria for gas was adopted.

skin_corrosion_irritation.hazard_statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on a result of "severe irritation" in a rabbit test (PATTY (5th, 2001)), a report of "0.1 mL produced severe necrosis in rat" (HSDB (2003)) and information of pH 11.5 (9.7 g/L) (GESTIS (access on Aug. 2009)), the substance was classified into Category 1.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: There is a result of "severe irritation" in a rabbit test (PATTY (5th, 2001)) and a report that severe corneal damage to obscure iritic examination, and conjunctival erythema, chemosis, and discharge were observed at 24, 48, and 72-hour post-instillation into the conjunctival sac of rabbits with no apparent remission occurring throughout 7-day observation period (HSDB (2003)). The substance has a pH 11.5 (9.7 g/L) (GESTIS (access on Aug. 2009)) and is classified as corrosive for the skin. Based on above information, the substance was classified into Category 1.

carcinogenicity.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data from in vivo mutagenicity tests. From in vitro mutagenicity tests, there is a report of a negative Salmonella typhimurium reverse mutation assay (NTP DB (access on Aug. 2009)).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.classification: Category 2 (central nervous system), Category 3 (respiratory tract irritation)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause damage to organs (central nervous system) May cause respiratory irritation (respiratory tract irritation)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: In a rat acute oral toxicity test there are reports that lethargy and mortality were observed at 215 or 464 mg/kg and higher dose levels which are within the guidance value range for Category 1 or Category 2, respectively, (HSDB (2003)). In a rat acute inhalation test, observed depression persisted up to 24-hour post-exposure following exposure at 6.3 mg/L/1h (3.2 mg/L/4h). The exposure level is within the guidance value range for Category 1, (HSDB (2003)). Additionally, there is a report of CNS depression as toxicity of the substance (DHP (13th, 2002)). Although above information correspond to Category 1 (central nervous system), it was classified into Category 2 (central nervous system) because of information in List 2. Additional reports report that exposure to vapours produced respiratory tract irritation in rats (HSDB (2003)) and that mucous membrane irritation and chest discomfort occur during human exposure (PATTY (5th, 2001)). Therefore, the substance was classified into Category 3 (respiratory tract irritation).

aspiration_hazard.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
aspiration_hazard.rationale: Although it is reported that repeated inhalation exposure in rats (vapour, 7 hr * 50 exposures) at 200 ppm (0.8 mg/L) produced changes in liver and kidney weights, reduced growth, and death (HSDB (2003)), classification was not possible due to lack of other test data.

acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classified into Category 2 from its 96h-LC50 = 7 mg/L for fish (Goldfish) (pH = 9.4) (AQUIRE, 2010).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classified into Category 2 since its acute toxicity is Category 2 and adequate data on rapid degradation are not available.
